column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-crime-mayor-idUSKCN10F2L2	California mayor charged in youth camp strip poker scandal	"
By Steve Gorman
The mayor of Stockton
column2: California
column3: was arrested on Thursday on a felony eavesdropping charge stemming from a strip poker game he is accused of surreptitiously recording at a summer camp he hosts for disadvantaged inner-city children
column4: prosecutors said.Mayor Anthony Ray Silva
column6: was also charged with three misdemeanor counts - contributing to the delinquency of a minor
column7: child endangerment and furnishing alcoholic beverages to individuals under the legal drinking age of 21
column8: according to a criminal complaint filed in court.Silva is accused of using his cellphone to make an audio recording of conversation among several young people
column10: who were playing strip poker with the mayor inside his cabin at the camp.Prosecutors said in a media statement it was evident that the participants
column12: were recorded against their will. Amador County District Attorney Todd Riebe said those present besides the mayor included two to three females and three males
column13: all ranging in age from 18 to 20.The criminal complaint further accuses Silva of supplying alcohol to six underage youths. Prosecutors said some were camp counselors.

column1: The incidents
column2: according to prosecutors
column3: took place last August at the Stockton Silver Lake Camp in Amador County
column4: which lies in California Gold Country on the edge of the Sierras northeast of Stockton.In addition to hosting unprivileged children at the city-leased camp each summer
column5: Silva has served as president of the Boys & Girls Clubs of Stockton for the past six years.

column1: Silva's lawyer
column2: Mark Reichel
column3: told Reuters his client ""will be vindicated"" and suggested the case was politically motivated
column4: noting that the mayor
column5: a Republican
column6: faces a tough election run-off in November against a Democratic city councilman.Asked whether Silva was playing strip poker with youths from his camp
column7: Reichel replied
column8: ""I highly doubt it."" Reichel added
column9: ""I can't wait to fight them in court
column10: so we can expose the epidemic of kids at summer camp playing strip poker.""Silva was elected mayor of Stockton
column14: months after the municipality filed for bankruptcy. The city emerged from bankruptcy protection in February 2015.

column1: Silva
column2: who is not married
column3: was arrested by FBI agents Thursday morning at the camp and released on $20
column4: 000 bond later in the day. His next court date is Aug. 18. If convicted of the charges
column5: he could face up to three years in prison. (Reporting by Steve Gorman; Editing by Tom Brown
column6: Bill Rigby and Bernard Orr)"	[]	[]

By Jeff Mason and Timothy Gardner
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama confirmed on Thursday that Donald Trump will get national security briefings ahead of the November election
column2: but he warned the Republican candidate
column3: whom he has called ""unfit"" for office
column4: that information from the meetings must be kept secret.Obama

column7: a New York businessman who has proposed temporarily banning Muslims from entering the United States and building a wall on the U.S. border with Mexico.On Tuesday Obama questioned why leading Republicans have not withdrawn their support for their presidential nominee. On Thursday he dismissed as ridiculous Trump's claims that the election may be rigged.""Of course the elections will not be rigged. What does that mean?"" Obama said with exasperation. ""If Mr. Trump is up 10 or 15 points on Election Day and ends up losing
column8: then maybe he can raise some questions. That doesn't seem to be the case at the moment.""Trump is trailing Clinton in polls.

column1: Despite his disdain
column2: Obama said Trump would get the top secret briefings on world crises and security threats to which he

column4: speaking to reporters at the Pentagon
column5: made clear that both candidates would be treated equally.

column10: and that means being able to receive these briefings and not spread them around.""Trump has placed blame on Clinton and Obama for the rise of Islamic State

column1: By Steve Holland and Emily Stephenson
| WASHINGTON/PORTLAND

column1: WASHINGTON/PORTLAND
column2: Me. Supporters of Republican Donald Trump urged him to get back on message on Thursday after a week of dropping opinion poll numbers and a war of words with ranking Republicans over his U.S. presidential campaign.In response to the criticism

column6: on Thursday

column8: Trump has exasperated many supporters by getting bogged down in a public spat with the parents of an American soldier killed in Iraq and some fellow Republicans.Billionaire investor Wilbur Ross said he still backed Trump

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-republicans-idUSKCN10F10U	In slap at Trump
column2: some wealthy Republicans campaign for Clinton	"

column1: By Olivia Oran and Amanda Becker
| NEW YORK/WASHINGTON
NEW YORK/WASHINGTON Groups of wealthy Republicans unhappy with Donald Trump have been privately courting prominent peers to join them in backing Democrat Hillary Clinton's U.S. presidential bid
column2: several people involved in the effort told Reuters.They say they are seeking money and endorsements from other Republicans disillusioned by Trump
column3: their party's candidate for the Nov. 8 presidential election. Some have received encouragement from Clinton and members of her campaign staff. ""I made the decision that I wouldn't be able to look at my grandkids if I voted for Trump
column4: said Dan Webb
column5: a former federal prosecutor and a self-described ""Republican for decades"" working to win over prominent Republican business people in Chicago.Trump
column6: a New York developer making his first run at public office
column7: has made traditional Republican donors uneasy with inflammatory statements about women
column8: Mexicans
column10: among others. Big-name Wall Street donors can make a difference for Clinton. They could inject big money into a campaign. They might influence moderate Republicans to switch sides. Their support of Clinton challenges Trump's assertion that his business successes make him a better candidate for president.With the political conventions barely over
column11: the Republican effort to fundraise for Clinton is at an early stage. Some of the groups have yet to receive contributions because they must still file paperwork under campaign finance rules.Trump spokeswoman Hope Hicks declined to comment for this story. Clinton spokesman Jesse Ferguson said business leaders are supporting Clinton because of her economic plan and because Trump ""cannot be trusted to lead our economy.""

column1: WARY OF TRUMP
Groups formed to support Clinton include Republicans for Her 2016
column2: run by Republican lobbyist Craig Snyder; a grassroots organization called R4C16
column3: led by John Stubbs and Ricardo Reyes
column4: officials in former President George W. Bush's administration; and the Republican Women for Hillary group co-led by Jennifer Pierotti Lim
column5: an official at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. The first two groups are acting independently of Clinton's own effort. The third is acting in concert with her campaign.""We wanted to go out there and be the voice for Republicans who were feeling wary about Trump and weird about publicly endorsing Hillary
column6: said Pierotti Lim
column7: who spoke at the Democratic National Convention at the Clinton team's invitation.Webb
column8: a partner at law firm Winston & Strawn
column9: said he began his outreach after being approached by billionaire investor J.B. Pritzker and longtime Clinton associate Lanny Davis. Pritzker and Davis could not be reached for comment.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: billionaire hedge fund manager Seth Klarman said he would work to get Clinton elected because of comments by Trump he found ""shockingly unacceptable."" Although Klarman
column3: who is the president and chief executive of The Baupost Group
column4: is a registered independent
column5: a review of filings shows his political giving has largely benefited Republicans over the years
column6: including some of Trump's rivals in the state-by-state nominating contests this year.Jim Cicconi
column7: a former Reagan and George H.W. White House staff member and lifelong Republican
column8: said he went public with his decision to support Clinton ""to encourage others in my situation to do the same thing.""""I feel like I need to do something more than quietly pulling the lever
column9: he said. ""I'm willing to assist the campaign in any way that they want me to help.""

column1: WHITMAN
column2: BLOOMBERG BACK CLINTON

column1: Spearheading in part the Clinton effort to woo Republicans on Wall Street is Democratic strategist Leslie Dach
column2: a former Walmart executive and aide to Bill Clinton
column3: sources close to the Clinton campaign said. People familiar with the Clinton drive say the Democratic nominee herself has spoken to Republican business leaders
column4: including Hewlett Packard Enterprise Chief Executive Meg Whitman
column5: who endorsed Clinton on Tuesday.Clinton deputies courted former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg ahead of a rousing speech he gave at last month's Democratic National Convention that urged Wall Street to support her.Whether Bloomberg
column6: a self-made billionaire media mogul and an erstwhile Republican
column7: will play a role in courting other Republican business leaders has yet to be determined
column8: a source close to the discussions said.While some major donors are hesitant to back Trump
column9: the candidate over the last month has pulled in millions of dollars in small-money donations to boost total contributions to more than $80 million for Trump's campaign and the Republican Party
column10: nearly matching Clinton's $90 million haul during the same period. (Additional reporting by Jennifer Ablan
column11: Lawrence Delevingne and Jessica Resnick-Ault in New York and Svea Herbst-Bayliss in Boston; Writing by Lauren Tara LaCapra; Editing by Howard Goller and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Clinton'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-security-idUSKCN10F2OQ	Former U.S. security officials call Trump comments 'disgraceful'	"
WASHINGTON A group of former U.S. national security officials
column2: including some who have worked for top Republicans
column3: called Donald Trump's recent comments about NATO
column4: Russia's annexation of Crimea and other matters ""disgraceful"" in a letter released on Thursday.In the last month
column5: the Republican presidential nominee has suggested he might not defend NATO allies if they did not spend more on defense
column6: appeared to invite Russia to hack the emails of Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton and suggested he might accept Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea from Ukraine.""These are disgraceful statements that betray our longstanding values and national interests embraced by presidents of both parties
column7: said the open letter first reported by The Washington Post.Most of the 37 who signed the letter appear to be Democrats
column8: including Madeleine Albright and Leon Panetta
column9: respectively former secretaries of state and defense
column10: but others served under Republican presidents and lawmakers.

column1: Among these
column2: John Bellinger was State Department legal adviser for former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice
column3: and Randy Scheunemann
column4: a neoconservative political operative
column5: was foreign policy advisor to Republican John McCain's presidential campaign.

column1: Other signatories included former career diplomats Tom Pickering
column2: Bill Burns
column3: Nicholas Burns and Marc Grossman
column4: all of whom served as undersecretary of state for political affairs
column5: effectively the third-ranking U.S. diplomat.  The letter is the latest in a series from former national security officials dismayed at the thought of a Trump presidency. In March
column6: more than 90 Republican foreign policy veterans
column7: including former Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick
column8: signed a letter pledging to oppose Trump and saying his proposals would undermine U.S. security.

column1: (Reporting by Arshad Mohammed; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Clinton'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-ryan-idUSKCN10F2KJ	House Speaker Ryan: No point in lame duck vote on TPP deal	"

WASHINGTON U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan said on Thursday that he saw no point in bringing up the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal for a vote in any ""lame duck"" session of Congress later this year after November elections
column2: because ""we don't have the votes.""""As long as we don't have the votes

column5: a Republican

column7: Obama administration officials have pledged to make a major push in coming months to persuade the Republican-majority Congress to pass TPP. Backed by dozens of business and industry groups
column8: officials  from the U.S. Commerce Department
column9: the U.S. Trade Representative's office and the White House say they are continuing to talk with individual lawmakers about the merits of the deal
column10: including its consequences for U.S. leadership in Asia.

column1: But Ryan said the Obama administration had negotiated a deal that ""cost them dozens of votes in Congress
column2: and said the Democratic president needed to renegotiate some components. The speaker said some agricultural and labor provisions needed fixing
column3: and he also believed the deal would reduce intellectual property rights for biologic drugs and pharmaceuticals.

column1: For U.S. drugmakers the deal could reduce the patent protection period to eight years from the current 12. Senator Orrin Hatch
